item.title: IBM CEO Rometty to Attend Masters
item.description: Virginia Rometty's case presents a uniquely delicate problem for IBM and the tournament amid the now-raging controversy over whether the all-male golf club should admit female members.

item.title: 'London Whale' Rattles Debt Market
item.description: Hedge funds and others have been puzzled by unusual movements in some credit markets and buzzing about the identity of a trader dubbed "the London whale." That trader, according to people familiar with the matter, is with J.P. Morgan Chase.

item.title: Coty Knocks on Brazil's Door
item.description: Coty's effort to buy Avon reflects in part its desire to get a hold of the cosmetics company's extensive door-to-door sales operations in Brazil.

item.title: Crude or Refined? Delta's Fuel Gambit
item.description: Delta Air Lines is considering entering the oil-refining business by buying an idled ConocoPhillips refinery near Philadelphia to reduce the rising cost of aviation fuel.

item.title: NBC Signs Deal to Keep Lauer on 'Today'
item.description: NBC News has signed a new "long-term" deal to keep Matt Lauer in his role as co-anchor of the "Today" show.

item.title: Alcoa to Curb Alumina Production
item.description: Alcoa plans to cut alumina production by about 2% this year, in an effort to match output with its plans to reduce smelter capacity.

item.title: Retailers Pick Up Momentum
item.description: U.S. retailers generally reported strong sales for March, as warmer weather and appealing fashion styles attracted shoppers. Gap and Target were among the standouts, while Costco faltered.

item.title: PPG to Lay Off 2,000
item.description: PPG Industries said it plans to shed 2,000 jobs and take $328 million in special charges, in the latest sign of the strain Europe's industrial economic slowdown has placed on chemical makers.

item.title: J.C. Penney Cuts Headquarters Staff
item.description: J.C. Penney moved forward with a plan to revamp operations, letting go about 14% of staff at its Plano, Texas, headquarters to streamline its management structure.

item.title: Facebook Tags Nasdaq
item.description: Nasdaq OMX has scored the listing of Facebook shares, winning what has been seen as the most-coveted listing among a new guard of Internet businesses.

item.title: Current TV: Cable Survival Test Case?
item.description: Al Gore's Current TV may yet be a test case for little cable channels fighting to survive.

item.title: GM, Toyota Report China Sales Gains
item.description: GM posted double-digit first-quarter sales gains in China while Toyota posted a 2% sales increase over a year ago, as the world's top two auto makers contend with slower growth in the world's largest auto market.

item.title: Ford to Boost Production in China
item.description: Ford Motor unveiled plans to invest $600 million to turn the inland Chinese city of Chongqing into its major manufacturing center for passenger cars.

item.title: Judge Temporarily Halts Hospital Merger
item.description: A federal judge temporarily halted the merger of two Rockford, Ill., hospitals in a victory for the FTC, which is targeting deals it says create local health-care monopolies.

item.title: Pain-Pill Crackdown Spreads
item.description: A federal crackdown on abuse of prescription pain pills has reached the nation's biggest drugstore chain, Walgreen, with drug agents searching six stores and a distribution center in Florida.

item.title: China Tries the Finer Things
item.description: The challenge of Italian yacht maker Ferretti Group is preserving the brand's mystique as financial backing is provided by owners from a country with little reputation for luxury.

item.title: Apple Contractor to Raise Wages
item.description: Hon Hai Precision Industry, maker of Apple's iPads and iPhones, plans to raise wages for its employees in Taiwan "significantly."

item.title: RIM Loses More Senior Executives
item.description: A number of senior-level executives at BlackBerry-maker Research In Motion have left the company in recent days amid a broad review of the company's strategic options.

item.title: Sears to License Kenmore, Craftsman Names
item.description: Sears is licensing the names of its most well-known brands, Kenmore, Craftsman and DieHard, in an effort to expand their appeal through other retailers.

item.title: Citi Cited Over Laundering Lapses
item.description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency cited Citigroup for failing to comply with a federal law that requires banks to establish protections against money laundering.

item.title: Bristol-Myers Still Looking at Amylin
item.description: Bristol-Myers Squibb remains interested in Amylin Pharmaceuticals and is watching the drug maker closely to see how it responds to investor Carl Icahn's demand that Amylin pursue a sale.

item.title: SEC Probing Eni, Total Over Libya OperationsI
item.description: The SEC has sent formal requests for information to Italy's Eni and France's Total related to the companies' Libyan businesses, the companies disclosed in regulatory filings.

item.title: Investors' Prying Eyes Blinded by New Law
item.description: An analysis for The Wall Street Journal lends some support to the bill's detractors, who say easing regulations will lead to more financial problems and fraud, and make it more difficult for investors to detect those issues.

item.title: Dell to Buy Make Technologies
item.description: Dell is buying Make Technologies, a legacy-software modernizer, as the computer maker boosts its services for business customers. Terms of the deal weren't disclosed.

item.title: Ruling Likely Soon in Martin Marietta-Vulcan Case
item.description: Martin Marietta Materials is expected to find out as soon as next week if its $5.5 billion hostile bid for Vulcan Materials could be derailed by previous confidentiality agreements between the two companies.

item.title: Exelon Taps Federal Loan for Solar Farm
item.description: Exelon said money from $646 million in federal loans backing construction of the giant Antelope Valley solar farm near Los Angeles has started to flow. Exelon bought the project from First Solar and will pay the solar company to build and operate the plant.

item.title: Boeing Deliveries Climb 32%
item.description: Boeing's first-quarter deliveries of commercial aircraft climbed 32% from a year earlier and also strengthened from the prior quarter.

item.title: Software Maker Open Solutions Attracts Suitors
item.description: Private-equity owners of financial-industry software developer Open Solutions have attracted interest in a potential sale of the Glastonbury, Conn., company.

item.title: Amid Setback, Spectrum Pharma to Buy Allos
item.description: As prospects dimmed for one of its own cancer drugs, Spectrum Pharmaceuticals is poised to land another cancer drug with its planned acquisition of Allos Therapeutics.

item.title: Spouses of Madoff Sons Face Claims
item.description: The trustee seeking to recover assets for victims of convicted Ponzi scheme operator Bernard Madoff can pursue some claims against the current or former spouses of his sons, a federal judge ruled.

item.title: Kodak Aims to Sell Lease on Billboard
item.description: The lights will go out on the Kodak name in New York's Times Square if the imaging company wins bankruptcy-court approval to transfer the lease to its giant digital billboard there.
